section.title: Com Sg. vs. Loc Pl.
section.p: Comitative singular and locative plural are homonymous in Northern Sámi. This is the biggest unsolved topic in the sme disambiguation file. What makes the topic so difficult to resolve is the fact that both comitative and locative can function as arguments of verbs and nouns as well as adjuncts. Arguments are fixed within the verbs subcategorization frame. Adjuncts are optional and supply additional information. The border can be difficult to draw.

section.title: Locative
section.p: The locative is quite flexible with respect to it´s functions, which usually makes it rather difficult to exclude it as a potential case.
Theta roles according to Sammallahti: GÁLDU, HÁLDDAŠEADDJI, BÁIKI, LUOBAHEADDJI
GÁLDU: Máhtte bođii Mázes.
HÁLDDAŠEADDJI: Juhána beana lea Máhtes.
BÁIKI: Máhtte orru Mázes.
LUOBAHEADDJI: Máhtte oaččui Márehis sabehiid.

section.title: Comitative
section.p: Comiative can have either an instrumental, a sociative or another idiosyncratic (idiomatic) function. Nickel describes comitative in object or adverbial position with two main connotations: instrumental and relational.
such as in: Dat láve álo riidalit isidiin.

section.title: Disambiguation can be attempted with respect to:
1. The subcategorization frame of verbs:
section.p: There are illative verbs, comitative verbs, locative verbs and verbs that have variants with different subcategorization frames. Verbs taking oblique objects, such as luohpat+Loc that helps in so far as we can exclude variant 6, which means if we only have one argument the situation is unambiguous
Unless: there are homonymous variants of a verb with different subcategorization frames:
In the case of borrat, the verb has a transitive and intransitive variant:

ul.li: Mun boran. (Used in the same way as the intransitive boradit: Mun boradan.)

section.title: 2. Number disambiguation
section.p: Some words are not used in plural/singular

section.title: 3. Word order
section.p: Usually the argument or adjunct can stand to the left or right of the verb or noun.
Is there a certain order of adjuncts or arguments?

section.title: Several locatives
section.p: There can be more than one locative in a sentence

ol.li:
one verb or noun
locatives with the same function (theta roles respectively adverbial functions) have to stand next to each other, one of them is a specification of the other such as in:
I live in Berlin, in Germany.
locatives with different functions do not have to be in neighbouring positions

several verbs and/or nouns
that means different verbs and nouns can have a locative with the same function as adjuncts and arguments

section.title: Several comitatives
section.p: There can be more than one comitative in a sentence

ol.li:
one verb or noun
comitatives with the same function
comitatives with different functions
*Mon stoagan iežan rátnáiguin vávváiguin. - I play with my friends with dolls.
Mon stoagan iežan rátnáiguin vávváiin. - I play with my friends with a doll.
Mon stoagan vávváiguin iežan rátnáiguin. - I play with dolls with my friends.
Iežan rátnáiguin mon stoagan vávváiguin. - With my friends I play with dolls. (topicalization when the following question is answered: Geaiguin don stoagat vávváguin? - With whom do you play with dolls?)

section.title: 4. Signal words
section.p: Usually work together with verbs and indicate a particular case
Examples are oktii (+Com), searválagaid (+Com)

section.title: 5. Heads
section.p: Constructions where a head chooses a locative or comitative substantive can have different forms: examples for this are:

ol.li:
## Mii leat lihkostuvvan bures dáinna prošeavttain.
The verb "lihkostuvvat" chooses the comitative "dáinna prošeavttain".

## Mis leat ovttasbargočoahkkimat PP-bálvalusain, skuvllain, mánáidsuodjalusain ja skulvadearvvašvuođabálvalusain.
The noun "ovttasbargočoahkkin" chooses the comiatives "PP-bálvalusain", "skuvllain", "mánáidsuodjalusain".
## Sieiddi bálvalemiin sturron eallu gohčoduvvui bálvvoseallun. Here the participle "sturron" chooses the comitative "bálvalemiin".

section.title: TIME expressions
section.p: Our TIME set consists of the following subsets:
section.source: SET TIME = MANNU | VAHKKU | BEAIVI | AIGODAT
section.p: TIME expressions are special with respect to their behaviour as adverbials. They can be time adverbials not only in one of the oblique cases, but also in genitive and accusative.
One gets the following syntactic tags from homonymy

section.title: 1. Genitive @GN>
section.p: jagi: Mis ii leat guolli ovdal go jagi loahpas.
áigodaga: Doaibmagolut leat kr 54 378', mii lea kr 964' eambbo go áigodaga gaskamearálašbušeahtta.
suoidnemánu: Suoidnemánu gaskamearalaš temperatuvra govvida muhtin muddui man bures šattut sáhttet lieđđugoahtit.

section.title: 2. Genitive @ADVL
section.p: Expresses according to Nickel how often or how many times something happens, when it happens and under which circumstances.
Mun ledjen doppe máŋgga geardde. - I have been there a lot of times.
Mun vuolggán boahtte vahku. - I am leaving next week.

section.title: 3. Accusative @ADVL
section.p: This is for expression where the time period in contrast to point of time is expressed.
Dat orui doppe vihtta jagi. - He lived ther for five years.

section.title: 4. Accusative @OBJ
section.p: such as in:

p.em: Lea leamaš liiggás oanehis áigodat oažžut bohtosiid oidnosii, čájehuvvo ahte easttadeaddji buohcanjávkan dárbbaha áiggi vai váikkuha nu movt lea sávaldat. (áiggi)

section.title: 5. Locative @ADVL
section.p: That applies to locatives vs. AccPx such as in:

p.em: Jus oahppi dahje ohppiidjoavku jávká lobihemiid osiid diimmus dahje olles diimmu.

section.title: 6. Nominative @SUBJ
section.p: This applies to vahkku which can be Nom, Gen and Acc
Jus vássá vahkku nu ahte dákkár duođaštus ii leat boahtán goddái, de galgá dát dieđihuvvot riikka stevdnevihtana bokte.

section.title: Resolving ambiguity between @GN> and @ADVL
section.p: Ambiguity in this case is usually avoided by a particular word order:
dan áigodaga goanagas (@GN>) vs. gonagas dan áigodaga (@ADVL)
áigodaga goanagas (@GN>)
dan áiggi goanagas (@GN>) vs. gonagas dan áiggi (@ADVL)
áiggi goanagas (@GN>)
jagi bušeahtta (@GN>) vs. bušeahtta jagi (@ADVL)

section.title: Px vs. Loc
section.p: Time expressions with numerals that modify them cannot/usually do not bear a possessive suffix.
Jagis 2002. - In the year 2002. / * Her year 2002.
